Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Understanding and Mitigating the Effects of University Closures due to COVID-19 on Black Students in Physics at the Bachelor's Level
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: COVID-19 resulted in campus closures and online learning at many colleges and universities. These campus closures disrupted connections to educational support resources, mentorship (informal and formal), and co-curricular activities that enrich the students’ experiences. This project studies the impacts of the COVID-19 campus closures (and move to online learning) on African American (Black) students pursuing bachelor’s degrees in physics and astronomy. While the data is available, this study will survey students to examine and document the impact of campus closures to educational persistence and resilience for this population of students. Findings may provide insights into how support structures (e.g. mentoring, tutoring, intrusive advising) can be effectively implemented when students undergo crisis, such as death of a close family member or friend, disruption to home support structures due to mass incarceration or deportation of one or both parents, serious illness involving the student or close family member. This body of work will provide a basis for examining the methods used to support students from other underrepresented and marginalized groups during crisis.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This study is being undertaken within the framework of outcomes gained by the American Institute of Physics (AIP) TEAM UP Task Force’s two-year study. Recommendations from this study enable physics and astronomy departments to better support African American (Black) students, many of whom already face well-documented obstacles to completing their degrees (due to other factors which are independent of COVID-19). Moreover, findings of this study extend to better understand and support students who undergo personal crises that require short-term or long-term absences from campus (even during normal campus operations). The project advances understanding of how to increase resilience toward degree completion for African American (Black) students during crises. These understandings could extrapolate to other marginalized populations of students. The importance of this work is that people's lives will be changed by increasing the relative percentage of these students who enter the technical workforce after having completed bachelor's degrees. The future job outlook in physics in the U.S. is promising, and access to these careers will provide the potential for a secure and stable financial future. This research lessens the likelihood that students will be left out of these job prospects due to the occurrence of crises during their pursuit of the bachelor’s degree. Crises that students face are more often personal crises, such as death of a close family member, serious illness to the student or close family member, effects of mass incarceration on families, or deportation of one or both parents. Likewise, economic crises resulting in the closures of some physics departmental occurring due to disasters such as storms, hurricanes, and tornadoes also present a disruption to physics departments and their students. This study bridges the learning from a sudden and collective crisis (i.e. COVID-19 campus closures) to well-designed actions that physics departments can take to address crises of a personal nature. This study provides useful contributions to better serve students and to prevent differential effects of crises on underrepresented minority students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This study's objective was to address the COVID-19 pandemic campus closures and how the Racial Justice Movement during the Summer of 2020 impacted Black/African-American students. The study disseminates ideas on how to sustain the equity-based values and systemic changes identified by the TEAM-UP Task Force study and ultimately support African-American physics and astronomy students through crises. The report is organized around a framework comprising four interrelated topics: the Impact of COVID: Departure from Normal; the Impact of the Social Justice Summer of 2020; the Transition to Post-Pandemic Operations; and Health, Wellness, and Well-being. These four topic areas capture the occurrences which could impact the five TEAM-UP factors of Physics Identity; Sense of Belonging; Academic Support; Necessary Personal Support, and Leadership and Structures. 

Survey Findings:  The survey’s total student population was 1,922, which included 4% Black/African-American students, 2% Black/Multiracial students; 70% White students; and 24% students of another race or ethnicity.  Survey results indicate that Black/African-American students’ physics experiences during COVID-19 were more positive between March 2020 and August 2021. Compared to students of other races/ethnicities, they felt more belonging in physics courses than before COVID-19, felt more confident that a physics major was right for them, felt more confident getting future employment or education opportunities than before COVID-19, and received more funding and internship opportunities during COVID-19.  

Site Visit Findings: The virtual site visit interviews were conducted at two university physics departments: University 1, a Predominantly African-American institution (PAAI) and University 2, a Predominantly White institution (PWI). Faculty, staff and students at both institutions described the transition to remote learning during the initial COVID-19 campus closures as difficult. However, the faculty, staff, and students from the two universities in our study had very different experiences. University 1 (PAAI) reported the transition as more frustrating, with a lack of guidance and inconsistent messaging from their department and university. Faculty lost contact with their students for several weeks, and this lack of communication led to decreased enrollment when they returned online.  They were motivated to support their students and help them succeed, meeting them where they were and supporting them through a variety of challenges. However, the remote learning transition for University 2 (PWI) was much smoother. Faculty and staff reported the transition felt “seamless,” and the university responded “well”. 

The virtual site visit interviews probed the participants on the stressors from the Summer 2020 Racial Justice Movement. Both University 1 (PAAI) and University 2 (PWI) faculty and staff recognized the need to acknowledge and understand the impacts of this trauma on students, and approached solutions to these challenges in different ways. Faculty members at University 1 (PAAI) focused on course content solutions. They made efforts to create space to discuss these issues during class and whenever possible included more scientists of color in their lectures. Faculty members at University 2 (PWI) focused on student-led solutions. They made efforts to encourage student activism and their desire to make positive changes. Department administration at University 2 helped students create a one-credit seminar course on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) topics, where they invited speakers and created proposals for action.

The virtual site visit interviews also documented challenges after the in-person transition in 2021-2022.  Not surprisingly, findings show that due to the challenges with remote learning, current and incoming undergraduate and graduate students were less prepared academically than before the pandemic. These observations were made by both faculty and students. 

Focus Group Findings:  The focus groups were conducted via zoom and were comprised of five Black students who were enrolled in undergraduate physics courses between the Spring of 2020 and Fall of 2022.  

The student experiences with these events varied from having very little impact to being career trajectory changing – often towards more socially impactful work in STEM.  Students also faced a range of challenges from losing community amongst peers to leaving their physics programs. 

According to the students who participated in the focus groups, some institutions and departments had an impact. To counter the social justice summer, institutions largely had vigils, conversations, surveys, and facilitated discussions. In some cases, faculty and staff members provided support which positively impacted the students. All students in the focus groups reported that, sadly, these efforts did not persist and much of the work died down except for a climate survey that was sent after one year— and was appreciated by the students.  

Broader Impacts:

Since the pandemic represents a time of crises for the world, a case could be made that the nation, and likely, Black/African-American students would benefit from the major outcomes of this study which would guide department leaderships and provide structural responses to students undergoing personal crises.The summative recommendations are found on our full report.  We anticipate the report to be disseminated on the American Instiutte of Physics website.
